definitions.definition: able to make good judgements based on reason and experience rather than emotion; practical
definitions.sensetop: sensible about somethingit is sensible to do somethingit is sensible for somebody to do something

examples.text: She's a sensible sort of person.
I think that's a very sensible idea.
I think **the sensible thing** would be to take a taxi home.
Say something sensible.
a sensible approach/decision/solution/option
Diplomacy is the only **sensible way** to resolve this dispute.
This is an eminently sensible approach.
We have to be sensible about this.
We are just asking people to be sensible about the amount of water they use.
It is sensible to have contingency plans in place.
examples.contextForm: it is sensible to do something

examples.text: It would be sensible for the government to take precautionary measures.
examples.contextForm: it is sensible for somebody to do something

examples.text: Ben's usually pretty sensible.
I wish you'd be sensible for once!
She was a sensible little girl, and would never get into a car with a stranger.
That wasn't a very sensible thing to do!
In the state I was in, this seemed a perfectly sensible remark.
That advice sounds sensible enough.
This approach seems very sensible to me.
Choose a sensible diet and stick to it.
sensible shoes
I am sensible of the fact that mathematics is not a popular subject.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘perceptible by the senses’): from Old French, or from Latin sensibilis, from sensus ‘faculty of feeling, thought, meaning’, from sentire ‘feel’.
